title.rendered: Whose Report Will You Believe?

content.rendered:
Good morning,

The LORD said to Moses, “Send some men to explore the land of Canaan, which I am giving to the Israelites. From each ancestral tribe send one of its leaders.” Number 13:1-2

People are always giving different reports on the same issue.  Many scientists at one time reported that the earth was flat, but a minority of people believed it to be round, as did the Bible state the same (Isa. 40:22)  At one time the scientific majority said the earth sat on a large animal, while the Bible had stated the earth floats free in space (Job 26:7).  And my favorite, many say you should never discuss religion or politics at a table, 2% of Christians disobey the majority’s word.

The Lord brought His plan to Moses to send out spies into the land (v.1) by the commandment of the Lord (V.3) were chosen one man from each tribe in Israel. Verses 4-16 describe the names of the rulers from each tribe. Verse 6 speaks of Caleb who was from the same tribe as Jesus (Judah) and verse 16 is when Moses calls Joshua.  These names are obviously the main characters in the account.  Moses lays out the blueprints of the assignment.  They were to bring back a report of the following: #1.  The People:  Strong or weak, few or many #2.  Land:  Good or bad, fat or lean, wood or not, fertile soil or poor soil? #3 Towns:  Unwalled or fortified #4 Tangible Evidence (extra credit):  Do your best to bring back some of the fruit of the land.” (It was the season for the first ripe grapes.) This was going over and above their assignment.

2 Reports returned, one from the majority, and one from the minority. The Majority report stated the following in their report:

Land:  Flowing with milk and honey People:  Strong.  They focused on the fact of the people of Anak that were allegedly giants (v.33).  It’s probably more important to say gigantic as a description.  Writings have been found from the Egyptians written on papyrus (13 Cent. BC) describing fierce warriors in Canaan 7-9 feet tall. Towns:  Walled and very great Fruit:  They brought a single cluster of grapes, carried on a pole by to men, along with some pomegranates and figs.

Verse 32 states “And they brought an evil report” to the children of Israel.  Those were the cold, hard facts! Beautiful land – ugly giants; what were they to do?

The Minority reported the following in their report: Well, one of the spies named Caleb silenced the people before Moses and said, and answered Moses’ question with this statement; “We should go up at once and possess it for we are well able to overcome it.” Now that’s an extremely different report, as different as liberals and republicans, night and day, east and west. The Israelite’s were faced with an important choice; who’s report were they going to believe? The minority, positive report, full of faith, adventure, and proactively, said, “We should go up at once and take possession for we are well able to overcome it” or the majority, evil, doubtful, already defeated, and may I say Satanic report saying “We can’t attack those people; they are stronger than we are”. Unfortunately, they believed the negative report and didn’t enter the Promised Land for another forty years.  Were Joshua and Caleb being presumptuous in their faith?  Perhaps these two knew that “giants” were no problem for a Giant God!  What is the final verdict? Duet. 1:35-38 shows how out of the twelve spies only Joshua and Caleb entered the Promised Land.  The ten were called by Moses rebellious, unfaithful, grumblers, causing the people to lose heart. None of the men of that evil generation Moses, said, would enter into the Promise Land, except Joshua and Caleb.  Funny,! what were the names of the other spies?, I can’t remember.

Application:  God has placed a dream, passion, destiny or promise in your heart, you must be willing to kill some giants of doubt, fear and unbelief, to attain it! We must go forward unafraid and not be so easily dissuaded from the aspirations God has placed in our hearts. If God has spoken to us about a promise he wants to bring to pass in our lives – lets believe him and be ready to fight some giants. Hang onto God’s promises and refuse to back down! Go forward, praying for courage and enter that Promised Land – it’s worth the fight!

Blessings

Pastor Phil

title.rendered: Open Your Mouth Wide, And I Will Fill It

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Psalm 81:10,”I am the LORD your God, Who brought you out of the land of Egypt; Open your mouth wide, and I will fill it”.

There are those times when things are not going on well in your life; the first question I suspect will run through your mind is “What did I do wrong”? Those are the times you begin to trace back to what might have started to bring you to this condition. When you are sick and go to the doctor what do they do? run some tests on you and ask about family health history. He is trying to see where what you have could started from. And if one of your family members had/have it, the conclusion would be, most probably that is where you may have inherited it from.

We come to Christ and we think the same also happens. The good question to ask, “When you got saved, what were you saved from if what you used to deal with has to follow you into the new life?” 2Corinthians 5:17 says, “Therefore, if anyone is in Christ, he is a new creation; old things have passed away; behold, all things have become new”. So  past failures are not factors into your new life and cannot negate the future. Many are down because they do not believe God loves them in spite off. There is nothing you and I can do to make God love us more or less. The feeling of condemnation about the past failures is stopping some from progressing. Paul comes and tells us in Romans 8:1, “There is therefore now no condemnation to those who are in Christ Jesus, who do not walk according to the flesh, but according to the Spirit”. If you are in Christ, you ought not to feel condemned for that was taken care off when He took all your guilt and shame upon Him on the cross. I must say that this only applies to those who are in Christ. How about those who are not, John 3:18, “He who believes in Him is not condemned; but he who does not believe is condemned already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is not believing that Christ is Lord (head knowledge) but believing and walking in that belief.

If that is settled, then we have our Lord reminding us to do something. Psalms 81:10 is very vital to my new life. “I am the Lord YOUR God”, which shows that He knows me and He has called me His. Then He reminds me of where he called me from sin and bondage. Egypt in this case is the type of the world. Him reminding me is not to make me depressed but reminding me of His goodness. Romans 2:4, “Or do you despise the riches of His goodness, forbearance, and longsuffering, not knowing that the goodness of God leads you to repentance?” His goodness brought me this far and I thank Him for that but He wants to do more. Open your mouth wide, and I will fill it, fill it with what? joy, laughter, confidence, peace, prosperity, hope, holiness, purity. He will only fill you if you open your mouth and He will fill you with what you have room for. Don’t linger on what could have happened, expect what will happen. Your history is not a mystery to God. Choose this morning to open your mouth wide because He will fill you.

Blessings

Ev

title.rendered: A Promise With A Price, by Jimmy Olang

content.rendered:
Good morning,

It gives me pleasure again to have my younger brother share devotion with us.

There are times when we find ourselves in the midst of some kind of a desert, a sea or a storm. In times as these, we as Christian begin to question God. We ask questions like,” How could you let this happen to me if you love me?”. When we are faced with situations like these, there are scriptures from the bible that help us understand God’s plan for our lives.

There are 3 stories in the bible that are different, yet they speak the same truth to us. If you look at the story of the Exodus of the Israelites from Egypt, the story of Abraham, and the story of David, what do you see as common about these stories? They are stories of promise. Stories of what God promised to do. In Exodus, God had promised to deliver the Israelites. In Abraham’s story, God had had told him to leave his land and go to the place where he would show him. He also promised to give him a son. In David’s story, God had promised to make him King. The other thing that is common with these stories is that all the promises that God made came at a much later time than what was anticipated by the recipients. Another similarity is that between the promise and the fulfillment of the promise, the recipients endured tough times, temptations, hardship, and at certain times gave up, wanting to look back, or wanting to take a short cut. When the Israelites were in the desert, things were so bad that they said to Moses, “We were better of in Egypt than here. Forget the promised Land and lead us back to Egypt”. When David was anointed King, He was constantly pursued by Saul. He was constantly fleeing and most times weary. When Abraham saw that his promise was not being fulfilled, he was getting frustrated. He tried to take a short cut by sleeping with his maid.

Today, God has promised us good things. He has promised to bless us. Jeremiah 29:11 say that “for I know the plans I have for you…” Our Destiny was already ordained by God before we were even born. He says, “before you were born I knew you..” This is the trick though. God never explains the process on how He is going to bless you. He doesn’t explain every step that you will go through, the tough times, the temptations and the hardship. He knows that if He lets you take a glimpse at the process, you will never take a step towards your destiny. If God had told the Israelites that they would wander in the desert for 40 years and struggle the way they did, they would have never left Egypt. If David Knew that he would be a target of Saul, he would have chosen not to be King. If Abraham knew the problems he would face when he left his home, he would have never left. The reason why the bible calls these men “The warriors of faith” is because no matter what they went through, no matter what the situation was, no matter how bad things were, they only had one thing going for them FAITH. They believed God. They never looked back at where they had come from. Going back was never an option. They realized that it was not by might, not by power, but by His spirit. Today we can learn from these men. God has given us promises. He has plans for us. A lot of times He shows us the promise, but He doesn’t tell us the process. He may have promised you a good job, but He will not let you know that maybe at some point you will have to leave your current place, either voluntarily or otherwise and go through some financial struggles. He may have promised you a ministry, but He wont let you know that maybe you will suffer some set backs. He may have promised you a good husband or wife, but He wont let you know that there are times that things will be so bad between you and your partner. big fights, even brake ups. It is up to us to say, “Lord, you promised, and I will stay faithful until it comes to pass. No matter what I go through, no matter how rough it is, no matter how much I want to give up, help me keep the faith”. Paul says, “I have fought a good fight, I have ran the race, I have kept the faith, and now I await the crown”. No matter what the situation is, we should remember that nothing can separate us from the love of God. Neither death, nor principalities not trials and tribulations. When he has tried us, we shall come forth as gold.

Blessings

Jimmy

title.rendered: Be ye Steadfast, by Judy Olang

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Isaiah 26: 3-6 “You will keep in perfect peace him whose mind is steadfast, because he trusts in you. Trust in the Lord for ever, for the Lord, the Lord is the Rock eternal. He humbles those who dwell on high, he lays the lofty city low; he levels it to the ground and casts it down to the dust. Feet trample it down-the feet of the oppressed, the footsteps of the poor.”

What does the word steadfast mean? It means unchanging, loyal, fixed, or constant etc. Have you ever been in situations or gone through life where you felt like you were between a rock and a hard place? You felt like the ground was sinking beneath your feet? You felt like the walls of this world were closing in on you and you are panicking and feeling like running out of air? Have you ever felt like you are the only one in this world going through difficulties and challenges that you feel like no one else has any idea what its like? Have you ever felt like the devil was sitting right on top of you and you were suffocating and everything you do and touch is messed up, nothing is working right? I will join you in saying YES! Even us as saved Christians go through all the above but what we do after we encounter hardships and challenges of this world is what matters most. I have seen so many professed Christians cuss God and leave their faith because life did not go their way and so they feel entitled to take matters into their own hands instead of looking up to God for help and strength and understanding. And Isaiah tells us very perfectly that when we fix our eyes on God, he will keep us in his perfect peace, that no matter what is going on around us we will be intact because we trust in him.

We need to channel our life line straight with God so that when troubles of this world come our way, we don’t loose focus, we don’t doubt. Let them find us steadfast/loyal/fixed on God and that is the one life line that the devil cannot and will not break. BUT if we have our life lines here on earth guess what? They will be broken and vanish never to be seen again. The one constant that never changes and is always there no matter what, is the mighty God we serve.  When my father died 14 yrs ago, I was turning 17 yrs old in a month’s time, my world came crushing down. I started thinking of how our lives were basically over for me, my siblings and my mother. I did not see how we were going to survive without my dad as our major bread winner and as a father. In my eyes we were finished, very bitter and angry at the Lord for a while  because before my father died we were facing a lot of hardships. Sometimes we did not even have food to put on the table, we went to bed hungry and sometimes my parents could not afford school fees and we would be home and no one really knew what was happening out there. They would see us and think we had a wonderful life but we didn’t. Anyhow, so when dad died a horrific sudden death, you bet I was angry with God but I remember my Pastor talking to me and encouraging me and something he said that I have always remembered and will was he asked me where my life line was connected. I realized then that I had my life line connected to my dad and that was not the way to go. So even though dad was never coming back I knew I would see him again and I reconnected my life line to God.

Has life been easier since then? NO, but, I thank God for the many other blessings in my life and the provision he has constantly given us at his perfect timing. When I see how far we as a family have come there is no way we would have made it if it wasn’t for a higher power which is God. So when life throws a curve ball at me, I know even if I’m hit, I find my strength in the Lord for Luke 10:19 “I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions and overcome all the power of the enemy; nothing will harm you.”

I would therefore encourage you with this, be steadfast in the Lord, don’t be lukewarm or like a chameleon (changes color depending on the surrounding) that when life is good that’s when you praise God and when life is going down the drain you cuss God and leave him. Let’s take a stand and I kid you not if you choose the Lord’s side, you will never be disappointed. So I leave you with this Psalm 37:7 “Be still before the Lord and wait patiently for him; do not fret when men succeed in their ways, when they carry out their wicked schemes.” And remember, unlike parents, God will not give you what you want just because you throw a temper tantrum, no, he does not work that way! Have a temper tantrum free day.

Blessings

Judy Olang

title.rendered: The Cross Is The Defining Factor

content.rendered:
Good morning,

John 19:38 After this, Joseph of Arimathea, being a disciple of Jesus, but secretly, for fear of the Jews, asked Pilate that he might take away the body of Jesus; and Pilate gave him permission. So he came and took the body of Jesus. …. 41 Now in the place where He was crucified there was a garden, and in the garden a new tomb in which no one had yet been laid. 42 So there they laid Jesus, …”

We have an account of the burial of the blessed body of our Lord Jesus. Jesus had just died, his disciples were scattered no where to be found, the women including Jesus’ mother were standing there helpless. There was no one to claim the body of our dear Savior. He had died like a criminal among criminals; the Father had turned His face away from looking at the wrath He poured on His Son for our sins. And this man who had healed the sick, raised the dead, fed the hungry, taught multitudes had no one or less people attend his funeral, leave alone claim His body but then here comes Joseph of Arimathea.

No mention is made in the entire New-Testament story, but only in the narrative which each of the gospels gives us of Christ’s burial, wherein he was chiefly concerned. Joseph of Arimathea was apparently a man of wealth, and probably a member of the Sanhedrin (the council that conspired to kill Jesus). According to Mark 15:43, Joseph was an “honorable counselor, who waited for the kingdom of God”. He was a disciple of Jesus, only secretly. He was not on the forefront like Peter, John and the rest. He was not known for the fear of the Jews. Maybe he feared that they would stop him from going to the temple, or kill him or he was concerned of what people would think of him.

What prompted this man to come out and identify himself as a disciple of a dead man and claim His body? I believe he died with Christ the day Christ died. His love for Christ propelled him to do something, knowing that Christ loved him first and demonstrated it by dying for him. 2Corinthians 5: 14 “For the love of Christ compels us, because we judge thus: that if One died for all, then all died; 15 and He died for all, that those who live should live no longer for themselves, but for Him who died for them and rose again.” No longer living for himself, no longer afraid of what people would think of him. He came out and identified with the man numbered among the thieves. The bible says that he had a brand new tomb, never used. Who knows whether he built that tomb for the body of our Savior Jesus Christ? While people did not believe that Christ would rise again, Joseph had faith that Christ would rise again and would need his tomb for the weekend.

Something happened that day that awakened Joseph of Arimathea. Seeing His Savior die on the cross naked, battered and bruised, the wrath of God poured on Him yet He said, “Father forgive them for they know not what they do”, something spectacular happened that day in the life of Joseph that he would not be silent no more. He had been secret  to this point, but not any longer. While those who walked close to Christ and known by everyone were nowhere, Joseph, least known Joseph “…asked Pilate that he might take away the body of Jesus; and Pilate gave him permission. So he came and took the body of Jesus”

God raised up this gentleman to interpose in him, that the scripture might be fulfilled. When God has work to do he seeks those like Joseph who are available to be used despite their background because they have seen the cost to appreciate the sacrifice. And for this reason, they can say “I’m part of the fellowship of the unashamed. I have the Holy Spirit power. The die has been cast. I have stepped over the line. The decision has been made. I am a disciple of His. I won’t look back, let up, slow down, back away, or be still …”author unknown. Have you been a secret disciple like Joseph,? Picture the cross of Jesus 2thousand years ago and let that compel you to die to everything that has led you to stay secret. The cross is the defining factor, Paul says, 1 Corinthians 2:2, “For I determined not to know anything among you except Jesus Christ and Him crucified”.

Blessings

Ev

title.rendered: Stir Yourselves Up, By Brother Ben

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Isaiah 64:7- And there is no one who calls upon Your name, Who stirs himself up to take hold of You; For you have hidden Your face from us, And have consumed us because of our iniquities.

Here the prophet Isaiah’s heart is poured out for us to see even till today. Here the heart of God is revealed to us. Here one of the great problems of Western Christianity is laid before all of us, may we now examine our own hearts. Time is ticking away, and there is much work to be done, but how many are truly concerned with the things that concern our God? How many are so consumed with enjoying this life that they are unable to turn their attention to the things of God? The word stir means to rouse oneself from spiritual drowsiness.

In Ephesians 5:8-14, Paul deals with the same topic as Isaiah here does. He reminds them that they were ONCE darkness, but are NOW light, and they are to walk as children of light, worthy of the calling of Christ. Are we still darkness, or have we truly come into the glorious day revealed by Christ being truly formed within us? He then goes on to instruct them to have NO fellowship with the unfruitful works of darkness, but to expose them. The church in America fails sadly at this point in many places, for they willingly fellowship with the world, and do what the world does. We must be a separate people, a holy people, a peculiar people. If the world is reveling in fleshly entertainment, drinking, smoking, swearing, and all the other things they do, what place does the church have here? None. We are called to a higher life, a holy life, where the glorious presence of our Lord shines from our lives in such a manner that it reveals all darkness around us. In I Peter 4:18, Peter quotes,” If the righteous scarcely be saved, Where will the sinner and the ungodly appear?”

Further in Ephesians 4, Paul states that all things are made manifest by the light, and the Greek here is translated that all things which are reproved, are thereby dragged out into the light. The holy light of the gospel, the testimony of Christ burning within the heart of the truly born again believer in Jesus, is purposed to expose all darkness. If sin still exists in our lives, if we live in condemnation, we will never bring this light, for we will be afraid to expose our own hearts. In Colossians 1:21-22, Paul declares that we have been reconciled through the death of Christ, to present us holy, and blameless, and above reproach in His sight. Above reproach means to be above blame or accusation, the true testimony of all who are genuinely washed in the blood of Calvary’s Lamb and continually walking by faith and obedience. Not the devil, nor this wicked world, has anything to point at in their life, they have nothing in them, and without condemnation they may declare the holiness of our God, and the coming judgment, knowing they are truly redeemed. What a confidence this is to have!

Lastly, Paul encourages in Ephesians 4, “Awake, you who sleep, Arise from the dead, And Christ will give you light!! Praise God, our Lord waits for each one to awaken themselves from the comfortable slumber of complacent Christianity, He waits to give abundant life, free of sin, to all who will stir themselves up, to all and any who will lay hold of Him by faith, and not let go until He blesses them!! Praise God for His unending mercy, for His faithfulness, and for His precious promises. Now, let us stir ourselves up, for he will not hide His face forever. Surrender all to Jesus, and never look back. Come to the altar, and present yourself as a living sacrifice, and leave your life there, don’t take it back, it belongs to Him if we are truly His. Stir yourselves up!-

In the sincere love of Christ Jesus, and for His glory alone, blessings

Brother Ben

title.rendered: The Foolishness Of God, Part 2, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

The foolishness of God is found in the Cross-

1CO 1:18, “For the message of the cross is foolishness to those who are perishing, but to us who are being saved it is the power of God”

With all the wisdom the Greeks & Egyptians had, with all the wisdom of all the cultures of all mankind in its totality.  In the wisdom of God they NEVER found God. Jews wanted miraculous signs, Proof by physical signs. Greeks wanted wisdom, Proof by human reasoning. Jews TRIPPED OVER the cross, the Greeks considered it FOOLISHNESS                     BUT When God gave Jesus He gave both (wisdom & the miraculous) in one.

And today the cross doesn’t make any sense to those that are perishing without Christ, because if they had Christ in their lives it would not be foolish to them.

The foolishness of God is found in foolishness of preaching his Word (v.21)

God said, “I’m going to make a way for the world to get saved, and I’m going to do it by something the world considers foolish, PREACHING” 1CO 4:10 says “We are fools for Christ…”  When you hear the word “preach” you may think pulpit, minister, church, yet it means one who proclaims the truth.  Bill Bright in his book “The Coming Revival” states that only 2% of Christians have evangelistic zeal and share their faith daily.   This is because many Christians have fooled themselves by swallowing the comfortable euphemism of “friendship” or “lifestyle evangelism.”  This is the kind where people congratulate one another that actions speak louder than words, and that if others know they are a Christian, they need not say anything about Jesus so long as they live exemplary lives.   This has been so dangerous a ploy of Satan, yet so many Christians believe this.

Too close, as I shared the gospel with a person I had just met, who was very open to the things of God, a Jewish woman yelled at me saying “keep your voice down, respect others beliefs, stop talking about Jesus so loud because I am Jewish.”  So I apologized for being insensitive in a public place and immediately changed subjects so as not to offend her. NO WAY!  I slammed her with the truth of God’s word telling her “I may lower my voice, although highly unlikely, but I will not stop talking about the Messiah that you need to save your soul from Hell, and by the way I respect Jesus more than anyone.”

Swallow truth, not comfort.  I will have more on the dangers of friendship or lifestyle evangelism tomorrow.

Blessings,

Pastor Phil <><

title.rendered: The Foolishness Of God, Part 1, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“But God chose the foolish things of the world to shame the wise; God chose the weak things of the world to shame the strong. He chose the lowly things of this world and the despised things–and the things that are not–to nullify the things that are, so that no one may boast before him.” (1 Cor. 1:27-29)

The one God calls and uses is not usually the brightest, strongest, most intellectual, or even the most spiritual person.  On the contrary, The one God calls and uses is not usually the brightest, strongest, most intellectual, or even the most spiritual person.

(Vs. 26-28) The foolishness of God is found in God giving humanly impossible tasks to seemingly unqualified people.

David = small Jewish shepherd boy with one stone and a sling conquers a giant Philistine warrior armed with a sword.  THE FOOLISHNESS OF GOD

Abraham = I want you to pack up and go out into the desert to a place that I will show you.  Sarah is going to have a baby.  You are no longer to be called Abram, but Abraham because you are going to be the father of many nations.  FOOLISHNESS OF GOD

Moses – I want you at 80 years old to go command the Pharaoh of Egypt to “Let me people go,” even though you have trouble speaking.  Stephen described Moses, as a man mighty in his words and works. Yet, Moses said, “O Lord, I have never been eloquent, neither in the past nor since you have spoken to your servant. I am slow of speech and tongue.”  The LORD said to him, “Who gave man his mouth? Who makes him deaf or mute? Who gives him sight or makes him blind? Is it not I, the LORD? Now go; I will help you speak and will teach you what to say.” (Exo. 4:10-12). “When a born orator comes to the place of saying I cannot speak then he has learned the fundamental lesson and is on the road of usefulness for God”.  (Watchman Nee).  It is in our weakness that God’ power is seen. (2 Cor. 12:9)

Little Boy – Give up your lunch (fish and bread) and after Jesus breaks and blesses the food it will feed 5,000 people.

(Vs. 18) The foolishness of God is found in the Cross, to continue…

Blessings

Pastor Phil

title.rendered: Freed To Serve Him, Part 2

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Acts 5: 17 “Then the high priest rose up, and all those who were with him (which is the sect of the Sadducees), and they were filled with indignation, 18 and laid their hands on the apostles and put them in the common prison. 19 But at night an angel of the Lord opened the prison doors and brought them out, and said, 20 “Go, stand in the temple and speak to the people all the words of this life.”

The disciples in early church as recorded in the book of Acts were powerful having been filled with the power of the Holy Ghost to be witnesses for Christ. After the departure of Christ, we see Peter assume the role of leadership over the disciples. We see him and the rest used mightily of God. The once upon a time coward Peter who denied Christ was bold enough under the unction of the Holy Spirit to preach Christ even to the point of being thrown in prison. Peter was no stranger to prison neither were some of the disciples as we read in the book of Acts.

In Acts 2, Peter preached the gospel and about three thousand people were converted, in Acts 3, Peter and John under the power of the Holy Ghost healed a man. They used the healing as a spring board to preach Christ but this led to their arrest. We need to note that the devil is not happy when the work of God is in progress. He does not want God glorified; he would rather take the glory and not God. And as long as you are determined to bring glory to God where you are, be ready to be under attack. The enemy will always say, “throw down your weapon and I will leave you alone, stop serving and I will leave you alone”, he will threaten to take away your freedom, squeeze, frustrate, try to silence and get you overwhelmed. His aim is to stop God’s work whatever the cost.

While they threatened the disciples to take away their freedom, they prayed for boldness to continue to preach the word of God stopping at nothing. Continuing in power in the early church, the bible says, Acts 5:12″ … through the hands of the apostles many signs and wonders were done among the people. And they were all with one accord in Solomon’s Porch. …. 14 And believers were increasingly added to the Lord, multitudes of both men and women, 15 so that they brought the sick out into the streets and laid them on beds and couches, that at least the shadow of Peter passing by might fall on some of them. 16 Also a multitude gathered from the surrounding cities to Jerusalem, bringing sick people and those who were tormented by unclean spirits, and they were all healed”. God’s work was on the move and this opened more to persecution.

Who tends to be a threat to the enemy? Those who are in the will of God, hungry to see Him glorified. Those who want to serve Him. Those who are not a threat are less under attack but those who have counted the cost and placed their lives on the line for the sake of Christ are opened to attack. And the attack I take a close notice of in the book of acts is freedom taken away from God’s people so as to silence them from proclaiming what they had seen and heard. But God will not let the enemy prevail, Acts 5: 17 “Then the high priest rose up, and all those who were with him (which is the sect of the Sadducees), and they were filled with indignation, 18 and laid their hands on the apostles and put them in the common prison. 19 But at night an angel of the Lord opened the prison doors and brought them out, and said, 20 “Go, stand in the temple and speak to the people all the words of this life.” They imprisoned them, God sent His angel to free them for His service. You would wonder why the Lord would not prevent them from going to prison. I believe the Lord used those times to confirm to them that they were in His will, to strengthen their faith as He demonstrated His power, and to prove to those who wanted to silence His work His power.

Whenever you feel imprisoned for doing God’s work, the Lord will always provide a way of escape by opening the prison doors for your release to keep serving Him.

Blessings

Ev

title.rendered: Freed To Serve Him, Part 1

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Genesis 39:6, “Thus he left all that he had in Joseph’s hand, and he did not know what he had except for the bread which he ate”.

To take a way a man’s freedom is to take away his reason for living. Watching inmates being interviewed especially those locked up in a confined environment talk candidly about what it means and feels to loose freedom. There are some who end up going crazy because their freedom is taken away due to what’s been done.

Recently I shared off Genesis 39, I feel compelled to look at it again as I gained some new insight off the passage. From Genesis 39-42, about 20 times the word ALL is used in reference to Joseph, which I find very important. The ALL I look at deals with his freedom given to him to act in some capacities. Going back to Genesis 39 where Portiphar made Joseph the overseer of ALL that he had, we see him living freely. Given freedom to control, direct, handle, in charge of all in Portiphar’s house. What is freedom? There are several definitions depending on the circumstance, for the sake of what I am sharing today, I would define it as the ability to act freely or a state in which somebody is able to act and live as he or she chooses, without being subject to any undue restraints or restrictions. A state of independence. Joseph had that in Portiphar’s house.  He was brought to be a slave, the way he lived suggested more than a slave.

Of course we know that freedom was taken away from him and confined in prison where he was no longer in charge of Portiphar’s house and his movement was restricted having been accused of attempted rape. All that he was in charge of was gone.

Who does not love freedom? Yet in the realm of our day to day lives we crave for freedom but we have an enemy who wants to take that freedom away from us. There are people right now reading this who at one point felt freedom in certain areas of their lives but right now feel caged, imprisoned, bound because an enemy has done this. The joy of being free is gone; you wake up each day feeling imprisoned in fear, doubt, depression, and defeat. Your financial situation has left you imprisoned to debt and you don’t feel freedom to serve the Lord like you should. Family situations, sickness have imprisoned you.

I have a word for us from the Lord, Psalm 146:7, “…The LORD gives freedom to the prisoners” but for what purpose? To be free to just enjoy ourselves and do what we want? No, Free to serve Him. That ought to be the drive for the desire for freedom. When God said in Exodus that he heard the cry of His people the Israelites, He’s main reason for coming to their rescue was not to bring them to the promise land to escape their bondage, prisons, it was to make them free that they may serve Him. Exodus 4: 22 Then you (Moses) shall say to Pharaoh, ‘Thus says the LORD: “Israel is My son, My firstborn. 23 So I say to you, let My son go that he may serve Me”. Joseph had the same freedom to serve God in Portiphar’s house, even in prison and when he was elevated out of prison to be Portiphar’s boss. Thank God for benefits too that come about when He frees. John 8:36, “Therefore if the Son makes you free, you shall be free indeed”

Are you craving for freedom this morning? Is this your cry? “God free me from my prison to freely serve You”?, that is my prayer, I am imprisoned in some areas of my life and only Him can free me from my prison and lead me to serve Him more and more freely.

Blessings

Ev

title.rendered: Breathe On Me

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Genesis 2:7, “The Lord God formed the man from the dust of the ground and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and the man became a living being”

Have you ever felt like nothing good was happening in your life? Something in your life was deteriorating or missing in your life? I have many times. There are times I was either gasping for breath or in need of life support. Well we praise God for He is the breath giver. When God formed the spirit of man in Genesis 2 He reached for the ground and picked up clay to form man. In as much as the man looked like what he was created to be, man could not function, see, move, stand, have knowledge, have feelings, emotions, have joy or smile because one important thing was missing, life.

We understand that God will not start something and not finish it, when God formed man, for His work to be complete; He had to breathe on that life less structure that man would become a living being. He created man’s spirit, He formed his body and He breathed on him. The breath of God is the seal and approval for something to function. Were it not for the breath of God which was neither created nor formed, man will be of no use, dead, nothing. With this understanding, I know that in as much as the body is there and it can be seen, without the breath of God to bring it to life, man cannot live. That breath that cannot be seen but felt is what makes a difference.

This is God’s breath we need in areas of our lives we feel dead. Breathe on me Lord, breathe in every part of my life that’s feeling dead, breath on my destiny, and breathe on my dreams and desires. Breath on me to stand and fight, breathe on me that I may be aware of what is accepted and what is not, breathe on me that I may keep on moving, breathe on me that I may always serve and worship You, Please breath on me Lord.

For one to be alive, there has to be breath and over and over again we see people who had died being raised by the breath of God coming back into their bodies. Yes the body was there and we know that the spirit does not die but the breath of God had departed and however precious the body was, it would not be kept around for it will decompose but the moment the breath of God came back to it, that which couldn’t see begins to see, that which couldn’t talk begins to talk, that which couldn’t reason, begins to reason and etc for the breath of God enables us to do the impossible.

I don’t know how my body functions and how my legs work and how I have the ability to move but one thing I know for sure, the breath of God gives me life. There are certain things I will never fully understand about who I am and where I am going but just understanding that He has breathed on me, gives me the assurance to know that I can make it because of Him. What part of your life feels dead, you feel like nothing good could come out of it, you have tried to nature it but it’s decomposing more and more? How about some things you have trusted God for? Let’s ask the Lord to breathe on us His breath again. Acts 17:28, “For in Him we live and move and have our being. As some of your own poets have said, “We are His off springs”.

Blessings

Ev

title.rendered: In The Presence Of The Lord, by Abraham Pulickal

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“Until I went into the sanctuary of God, then I understood their end.” Psalms 73:17

This beautiful Psalm (Psalm 73) was written by Asaph  who was one of the worship leaders in the house of God (probably at the time of king David.)..it starts with a complaint and grief Asaph expresses over his wonderful faith in God…He looks around at the conditions of the world and sees the wicked progressing, and the sinners living happily and this brings depression in his life…he questions himself and his faith in God…”Surely I have cleansed my heart in vain, and washed my hands in innocence..for all day long I have been plagued and chastened every morning”. Psalm 73:13-14….Do we ever go through situations where we may feel all this Christian stuff is useless…I can live without it…and progress in my life…yes we all do have such feelings when we look around in the world…if Asaph who was a worship leader can have such thoughts why can’t we have such negative thoughts..?…but then the latter part of this wonderful Psalm is very beautiful…vs 17 is the turning point….and this can change our thoughts too..Asaph carried his burden to the Lord in prayer and then he knew the end of all such people who do not follow the Lord…”Surely you set them in slippery places, you cast them down to destruction, Oh how they are brought to desolation as in a moment! they are utterly consumed with terrors…” Psalm 73:vs 18-19…and this is a fact….

We can enjoy a lot in our life but the fact is as Billy Graham says “True happiness comes not by doing what we like to do but by doing what we are expected to do”….God our creator expects us to be holy ……no one in the history would have ever lavished and enjoyed as King Solomon in the Bible…even though the Lord blessed him with great wisdom, he forgot the Lord and lavished in the worldly pleasures..and what was the end..his kingdom was divided and his end was miserable.. Solomon himself says in Ecclesiastics 12:13-14 “Now all has been heard, here is the conclusion of the matter, fear God and keep His commandments, for this is the whole duty of man, for God will bring every deed into judgment, including every hidden thing whether it is good or evil.”…He enjoyed at his best but at the end he lamented for all his deeds.. We can find peace and true joy only in the presence of the Lord as Asaph did…”For it is good for me to draw near to God. I have put my trust in the Lord God, that I may declare all your works” Psalm 73:28 ..The Bible also encourages us to believe in the Lord..”Do not let your heart envy sinners, but always be zealous for the fear of the LORD.There is surely a future hope for you, and your hope will not be cut off. ” Proverbs 23:17-18…also it tells us the end of sinners..”Do not fret because of evil men or be envious of the wicked, for the evil man has no future hope, and the lamp of the wicked will be snuffed out” Proverbs 24:19-20….

Psalms 1 gives us a wonderful distinction between a person who follows the Lord and one who does not follow the Lord…”Blessed is the man who does not walk in the counsel of the wicked or stand in the way of sinners or sit in the seat of mockers. But his delight is in the law of the LORD, and on his law he meditates day and night. He is like a tree planted by streams of water, which yields its fruit in season and whose leaf does not wither. Whatever he does prospers. ” Psalm 1:1-3…and also it wonderfully tells the end of the wicked people  “Not so the wicked! They are like chaff that the wind blows away. Therefore the wicked will not stand in the judgment, nor sinners in the assembly of the righteous. ”

So it is always wonderful to serve the Lord and follow Him and at the end of day we will never regret of our decision of following the Lord ….in depression we can get an answer when we go into the presence of the Lord in prayer as Asaph did…He will reveal Himself to us and fill us with the joy that surpasses all understanding…. for the Bible says ” In the presence of the Lord there is fullness there is fullness of Joy and in His right hand there are pleasures forevermore” Psalm 16:11, blessings Abraham

title.rendered: My Destiny

content.rendered:
Good morning,

John 15:5, “I am the vine, yea are the branches: He that abideth in me, and I in him, the same bringeth forth much fruit: for without me you can do nothing”.

Where there is a start, expect an end. Just because some don’t make it to the end does not mean it’s not there. If there is a start and end, it’s not a matter of how you begin the race that defines you, it’s how you end it that counts. You’ve heard of cases of people starting great but finished poorly then here comes other people who may have not had a happy and good beginning but in the end built legacies left behind. The question is, should my beginning be great and my end be poor or should I not worry much about how I start but work towards my finish?

John 15 calls us branches, our position is to abide and our destiny is to bear fruit, more fruit and much fruit. We are not expected to produce fruit, that is Christ’s job, we bear fruit already produced as long as we are attached to the true vine. Mark the way Jesus begins in John 15:1, “I am the true Vine…”, There were many other vines out there people could attach themselves to, He therefore distinguished Himself from the other vines. We need to be identified with our new birth as we understand who we are in Christ and we begin to bear fruit not because someone somewhere gave us identity but because we have found a Master who knows how to define us. With this understanding, we are not limited to what we have, but desiring to have much more. Be it growth, career, marriage, family, and ministry as long as you are attached to the true vine in other words being in His will, He will be faithful to do it. You and I are destined to make a difference wherever the Lord places us. We are the salt of the earth, rich (materially, spiritually, good works, emotionally). Your pew ought to change because you are sitting in it; your surrounding ought to shine because of God in you. Since you are abiding in Him, He will allow you to bear exactly what He had destined for you in life. I don’t want to reach heaven only to be shown things my heavenly Father stored for me in this life that I never utilized simply because I wasn’t abiding like I should have. Hanging out with the wrong people and being in wrong places and associating with wrong things will hinder my fruit bearing, in fact that may stunt our fruit bearing, the bible says, “Choose your friends wisely” and Psalms 1:1-3 sums it up.

This is true” …for without me you can do nothing”, “Destiny is not a matter of Choice: It is not a thing to be waited for, it is a thing to be achieved”  — William Jenning Bryan. Yes I started poorly as I was on my own, and being on my own caused me to mess up big time but when He redeemed my life, He changed my way of thinking, behaving, acting and dependence and now I am destined to abide in Him. Abiding in Him defines my future after all, He is the best in future making, my end will bring glory to His name and my testimony will touch many lives. Enoch walked with God, all he left was a testimony that he had pleased God. David walked with God, he left behind a testimony that he a man after God’s own heart. My encouragement to all of us, how poorly we started should not be our biggest concern, how we will finish the race while abiding in Him is what matters and what will count, 2Tim 4:7, I have fought a good fight, I have finished the course, I have kept the faith” blessings Ev

title.rendered: A Vision with a Task, Part 2, by Phil Sessa, Evangelist, inspired by Leonard Ravenhill

content.rendered:
Good morning,

I was unable to send you part 2 this morning due to unavoidable circumstances. Be blessed as you read part 2 of Pastor Phil’s devotion

A clear biblical vision will lead us to GO (a word of commission) 9And he said, Go, and tell this people, Hear ye indeed, but understand not; and see ye indeed, but perceive not.

I have heard it said that most of the church has as much zeal for evangelism as the world has for righteousness.  The Great Commission is a command, not a suggestion.  We are all called to go to the lost and warn the people of the coming judgment of God.  In light of Isaiah’s vision he knew he was sinfully filthy, and lived among sinfully filthy people.  When he was cleansed, how could he not want the other filthy persons, to know the cleansing from sin by the Lord?  Yet many are selfish, and would rather keep this Great News to themselves.  Imagine if you had the cure for cancer, and failed to share it with others. Would not that be a sin against all humanity?  How much more should those that have the cure for sin, in the blood of Christ, share the truth of the Gospel with those that have the cancer of sin.  There is only one remedy for sin, and that is the righteousness of Jesus Christ. “For the wages of sin is death (the cancer), but the gift of God is everlasting life (the remedy).”

A clear biblical vision will lead us to this imperative threefold vision, Isaiah needed to see beyond pride “King Uzziah died”, to his own sinfulness “I am undone, because I am a man of unclean lips; and I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips.  He realized that he was sinful, and those around him were sinful as well.  We must realize that our biggest problem and the world’s biggest problem is not the economy, housing, health care, the stock market, but SIN!  Our issues with health, money, death, etc…, all stem from sin.  Furthermore, our issues of abortion, murder, rape, suicide, homosexuality, fornication, pedophile, etc…  Romans states that “the wages of sin is death (6:23).”  Sin is our rebellion of God, shown in our transgression of His Moral Law (the Ten Commandments).  God must open our eyes to see sin for what it is.  Sin must become, as Paul said, exceedingly sinful (Roman 7:13).”

Leonard Ravenhill shares the following in His book Why Revival Tarries: “It was a vision of height – he saw the Lord high and lifted up.  A vision of depth – he saw the recesses of his won heart.  And a vision of breadth – he saw the world. A vision of holiness, Oh, beloved!  How this generation of believers needs the vision of God in all His holiness!  A vision of hellishness – “I am undone…unclean!” and a vision of hopelessness – implied by the words “Who will go for us?”

Ravenhill furthermore states, “In this hour – when the average church knows more about promotion than prayer, has forgotten consecration by fostering competition, and has substituted propaganda for propagation – this threefold vision is imperative.”

SWAT (SO WHAT APPLICATION TIME) Do you have a threefold vision?  Would another mature godly Christian attest to this in your life?  What role does pride play in your life?  Are you feeding into pride or allowing God to kill it in you, by submitting to Him?  If you are not a Christian, then are you ready to acknowledge the truth about your sin (measuring your sin against the 10 Commandments), confessing and repenting of your sin, and putting your trust in Christ (the only One that can cleanse you.)

1.      Teaching. What did I learn? 2.      Reproof. Where do I fall short? Why do I fall short? 3.      Correction. What will I do about it? 4.      Training in righteousness. How can I make this principle a consistent part of my life?

title.rendered: A Vision with a Task, Part 1, by Phil Sessa, Evangelist, inspired by Leonard Ravenhill

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Where there is no vision, the people perish: but he that keeps the law, happy is he (Proverbs 29:18 [KJV]).”

You must having a clear biblical vision: Many people have intentions, but they will only carry them out when it is convenient.  Those that have desires, will carry them out whether it is convenient or not.  Those that have a vision, but never carry it out, leaves the vision only in the state of the mind.  Can you imagine having such a vision to serve the Lord that it defines your very existence?  George Deakin said, “A vision without a task makes a visionary; a task without a vision is drudgery; a vision with a task makes a missionary.”

Isaiah had a vision, which he shares in Isaiah 6, ” 1In the year that king Uzziah died I saw also the LORD sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up, and his train filled the temple.” King Uzziah was a very prideful king, which is what eventually led to his death.  This reminds me that pride must die, in order to have a vision for the Lord.  Pride is to a faithful witness for Christ what kryptonite is to superman.  Pride kills!  Superman could be killed by Kryptonite, it drained his power until it would ultimately lead to his complete demise.   When someone is prideful, they have a vision for themselves, not for the Lord.  How can we have a vision for ourselves, and not one that the Lord has birthed in us, one which will glorify Him and not ourselves?  In Isaiah’s vision there are some poignant lessons for you and I in three dimensions as can be seen from verses 5,7,9.  Verse five, WOE (a word of confession), verse seven LO (a word of cleansing), and verse nine GO (a word of commission).

A clear biblical vision will lead us to WOE (a word of confession) 5Then said I, Woe is me! for I am undone; because I am a man of unclean lips, and I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips: for mine eyes have seen the King, the LORD of hosts.

We need to realize that we are undone, literally “cut off” from the Lord, apart from Him.  We are “dead in our sins and transgressions …(Eph 2:5).”  Only the Lord can awaken the realization that we are lost, dead, cut off from Him.  Charles Finney calls this “stage” a convicted sinner.  This confession is simply agreeing with God on the sinful state of a person’s life, and their desperate need for a savior.  However, it is a confession that stems from a torn heart as Joel stated when he spoke the words, “So rend your heart, and not your garments; Return to the LORD your God, For He is gracious and merciful, Slow to anger, and of great kindness; And He relents from doing harm (2:13).”

A clear biblical vision will lead us to LO (a word of cleansing) 7And he laid it upon my mouth, and said, Lo, this hath touched thy lips; and thine iniquity is taken away, and thy sin purged.

A sinner needs to be cleansed.  Isaiah’s vision occurred in the temple (Is 6:4) and was described in terms of the worship conducted there.  …The smoke of the altar (vv. 4, 6) filled the air, suggesting a sacrificial ceremony in progress. Whatever the particular nature of Isaiah’s vision, it was a pivotal event in his prophetic ministry (Apologetics Study Bible).  A prophet needs to be cleansed by the Lord in order to be effective for the Lord.  The Lord desires to “flow through” a clean vessel.  If you have ever had a plumbing problem in your home then you know the water sometimes can’t flow through pipes that have material build up and the water gets stuck and backed up in the pipes.  Our sin has a way of disallowing the living water flow through our lives. To continue, blessings Pastor Phil

title.rendered: Challenges Can Be Channels For Blessings, By Judy Olang

content.rendered:
Good morning,

It gives me great pleasure to have my beautiful God fearing wife to share devotion with us for the first time this morning. She is such a blessing in my life and I hope you be blessed as she shares. Ev

Genesis 45: 4-5, 7-8 “Then Joseph said to his brothers, “Come close to me.” When they had done so, he said, “I am your brother Joseph, the one you sold into Egypt! And now, do not be distressed and do not be angry with yourselves for selling me here, because it was to save lives that God sent me ahead of you.”…… vs. 7-8 “But God sent me ahead of you to preserve for you a remnant on earth and to save your lives by a great deliverance. So then, it was not you who sent me here, but God. He made me father to Pharaoh, lord of his entire household and ruler of all Egypt.” NIV.

I have been reading the Bible from cover to cover and this is my 3rd time starting from Genesis again and it always amazes me how every time I read the passages I already read before there is always a new revelation or a renewed understanding of what I am reading at the time. I am assuming we are all familiar with the story of Joseph, how his father Jacob loved him more than his other brothers and this resulted into jealousy among his brothers and they eventually sold him off to the Egyptians and they came back and lied to their father that Joseph died. I have always wondered if that was me and I survived like Joseph did, what I would want to do to my brothers, people that I thought loved me and were my own flesh and blood. Could you imagine the kind of feelings that would be going inside your heart? But what did Joseph do? I believe the first and the second time he encountered with his brothers he was tempted to revenge or get even but I believe he stopped himself because he was a man of God and he realized that what he was doing was not right.

We all face or have faced or will face circumstances like Josephs’ where your own people that you thought you could count on, sell you out. Family members that you thought had your back actually didn’t and friends that you thought were closer than a brother were just pests. So when you come into that situation what are we as Christians supposed to do? As humans we want revenge and we want them to suffer as much as we did, but is that the heart that a Christian should have? We are told in the bible that vengeance is of the Lord. So what do we do? We become the bigger people and return good for evil, we forgive even when it’s clear that the other person ought to be the one asking for forgiveness. We live in harmony and peace as much as possible with our neighbors and we carry ourselves like Christians. We watch our tongues, what comes out of our mouths should not make people’s heads turn with disbelief and wonder what kind of a Christian are you. We should truly love one another not just giving lip service but actually being it and doing it just as God loves us regardless of the many times we sin against him. And that’s what Joseph did, he revealed to them who he was and told them not to be afraid because I’m thinking they were afraid for their lives. If you meet someone you did something awful to, you know you are in trouble because that person will want to give you a taste of your medicine. So they were terrified and Joseph says no worries, forget about everything, you guys actually did me a favor, and you know what???? It was all God’s doing, he allowed all this to happen because he knew you all would need help and I am your help.  Isn’t that amazing?? Whereas sometimes or many times when we are faced with challenges like Joseph did, we want someone to blame instead of taking on that challenge as a blessing, a time to grow, to be pruned (as my husband would say), a time to reflect, and maybe a time to step back relax and come back stronger and wiser and more blessed. A challenge can be a blessing if channeled correctly.

So my dear brothers and sisters, when faced with impossibilities and challenges, remember Joseph went through all that, even being put in prison for something he never did but he rose, he became the head, from the pit that he was, he became a ruler. Rise above whatever it is you are facing and know that the Lord is fighting your battle, you are not alone! Believe it because we serve a mighty mighty God!! Blessings Judy Olang

title.rendered: The Inward Change, by Brother Ben

content.rendered:
Good Morning,

Ephesians 4:23-24- and be renewed in the spirit of your mind, and that you put on the new man which was created according to God, in true righteousness and holiness. The renewal here referred to by Paul is translated as a “reforming of the mental disposition of the intellect,” a complete renovation of the mind and heart. I believe the inner workings of God by His Holy Spirit in the lives of those truly justified by faith are greatly misunderstood today. There is a further, deeper work God desires to do, He desires to renovate our hearts and minds, not just cover them over. The work of the Holy Spirit is not to simply cover us over with the righteousness and holiness of Christ, but to impart within us the very character of Christ, true righteousness and holiness, as we put off the “old man” of sin, and “put on” the new man. Christ did not come to save us IN our sin, but He came and died to save us FROM our sin, from the very desire and inclination to sin. In order to wallpaper a wall, the existing wallpaper must be removed, otherwise the new paper will not stick well and can bubble and look terrible. Our hearts are the same. God does not desire to simply wallpaper over our old heart, but as Ezekiel 36:26 states, God designs to place within us a new heart and a new spirit, one after His own image. He desires to remove from us the old ways, the inner disposition that is continually set against Him. If He merely covered it over, this disposition would still remain, lurking around every turn, seeking to raise its ugly head every opportunity it could, occupying areas of the heart reserved for God alone. In Galatians 1:19 Paul refers to Christ being formed in us, and in Colossians 1:27 he states that Christ “in us” is the hope of glory. It is a change from the inside out, a glorious rebirth in Christ, a second work of grace, not a work we grow into over time, but a work done instantaneously by the Holy Spirit as we present ourselves as living sacrifices. This work of grace makes it possible to love the Lord with all of our heart, mind, and strength, for it removes this nature within us that is set against God and His holiness. There must be a change brothers and sisters. If we are the same spiritually as we were a year ago, something is wrong. So many today live under the title of “Christian”, but Christ has long departed, for they refused to go forward, they would rather hold on to the old life, the old ways we are called to forsake. Let today be the day you let go, let God have all of you, lay down your life, that you may be filled with all the fullness of God. Going onward to the Celestial City, blessings, Brother Ben

title.rendered: Take It To The Lord In Prayer, Part 2

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Isaiah 38:1-7, 2 Then Hezekiah turned his face toward the wall, and prayed to the LORD, 3 and said, “Remember now, O LORD, I pray, how I have walked before You in truth and with a loyal heart, and have done what is good in Your sight.” And Hezekiah wept bitterly What many fail to understand is that it’s not the faith and the prayer of someone else that works, it is your faith in God that drives you to cry out to Him. I’ve seen people get frustrated because a pastor or someone they considered more anointed did not pray for them leave alone lay hands on them when they were in need. Maybe the pastor sent someone else and they despised that person because they could not see God moving in a mighty way through that person leave alone having faith in God to call on Him while those who came around were to boost their faith. Look at Hezekiah who in the previous chapter spread a letter before the Lord in prayer. In the next chapter, we are told he became ill to the point of death. Isaiah the prophet is sent by God to tell Hezekiah to put his house in order for he was not going to die. Here is what fascinates me, Hezekiah does not send Isaiah the prophet back to God on his behalf, more like an attorney representing him, he chooses to turn to God himself knowing that the same God who heard him when he was to be faced by Sennacherib of the Assyria was the same God who would hear him. Then Hezekiah turned his face toward the wall, and prayed to the LORD, 3 and said, “Remember now, O LORD, I pray, how I have walked before You in truth and with a loyal heart, and have done what is good in Your sight.” And Hezekiah wept bitterly” Isaiah 38:2 Instead of getting frustrated with someone who did not pray for you or thinking that God will not hear your prayers, why not like Hezekiah reach out to God and remind Him of His promises for His children? Take it to the Lord in prayer. He wants to hear from you, your burden, your pain, your concerns, your struggles. You could change the course of your tomorrow, destiny because you cried to God while in trouble. He’s been waiting to hear from you. 1Peter 5: 6 “Therefore humble yourselves under the mighty hand of God, that He may exalt you in due time, 7 casting all your care upon Him, for He cares for you”. Praying is not a spiritual gift that some people have and some don’t, it’s a matter of humility and obedience. And God heard Hezekiah’s prayer, the same Prophet who brought him bad news, was the same prophet God used to give him good news, vs. 4 And the word of the LORD came to Isaiah, saying, 5 “Go and tell Hezekiah, ‘Thus says the LORD, the God of David your father: “I have heard your prayer, I have seen your tears; surely I will add to your days fifteen years. 6 I will deliver you and this city from the hand of the king of Assyria, and I will defend this city.”‘ 7 And this is the sign to you from the LORD, that the LORD will do this thing which He has spoken: 8 Behold, I will bring the shadow on the sundial, which has gone down with the sun on the sundial of Ahaz, ten degrees backward.” So the sun returned ten degrees on the dial by which it had gone down” Not only did God give him long life, He gave him more than he desired. Ephesians 3:20,” Now to Him who is able to do exceedingly abundantly above all that we ask or think, according to the power that works in us”. If Hezekiah did not cry out to God, we know he would have died, but his cry to God changed the course of things. Silent no more or you will miss what God desires to do in your life. Everything to God in prayer. Blessings Ev
